title: Various improvements, updated libraries and image features
body:
In this PR I updated all libraries, applied various code improvements, fixed tests in case of non enabled `chrono` feature and done some enrichments on the `embed_image` feature, now supports buffers.

I also added an useful function for the `Document` struct called `get_object_page()`, this function will return the Page `ObjectId` if found, useful for inserting certain element of another dependent `ObjectId` and another useful `remove_object()` function that is able to correctly remove an object from the page and the reference.

I also formatted the code with `cargo fmt` in order to be compliant to all Rust 2018 rules.

@J-F-Liu please wait before merging this, I'll to check if the `embed_image` is working properly because I think that is a little buggy. Maybe is not well tested as is not a default feature :-)

title: Merge document PDF logic with some fixes
body:
Introduction of **Dictionary** `extend()` function with a new and fixed `renumber_objects_with()` that will renumber objects ids starting from a custom ID, this is very useful in case of document merging.

I provided a working example [here](https://github.com/J-F-Liu/lopdf/pull/117/files).

title: Make pom dependency optional (but default)
body: A downside is that the add_barcode example is not compiled for the nom_parser feature. I don't know how to express that, or if it is even possible. It seems like a very minor drawback though.

title: Genericize Content to allow AsRef<[Operation]>
body:
This was just `Vec<Operation>` before, which may be the most common use-case and is also required for parsing, since allocation is necessary.
When creating a document allocating a `Vec` per `Content` may not be necessary though, so for that use-case allowing any `AsRef<[Operation]>`, like just a slice, is convenient.

Example:
```
let content = Content {
	operations: /* note the missing vec!*/[
		Operation::new("BT", vec![]),
		Operation::new("Tf", vec!["F1".into(), 48.into()]),
		Operation::new("Td", vec![100.into(), 600.into()]),
		Operation::new("Tj", vec![Object::string_literal("Hello World!")]),
		Operation::new("ET", vec![]),
	],
};
```

The operands for `Operation` still require `Vec`. If the `Operation` struct were to be replaced with an enum as suggested in #109 (with an additional `Custom { operation: AsRef<str>, operands: AsRef<[Object]> }`) that would become unnecessary though. If you like the idea I'd be happy to make a PR for that as well.

title: Make rayon dependency optional
body: Turn off rayon for wasm32/non-emscripten target.

title: Add as_str, as_str_mut methods to Object
body: I felt these convenience methods were missing.

title: Return Result from as_array_mut()
body: This makes the function behave like the other as_xxx methods.

title: Bugfix for xref_start.
body: I have some pdf files where the integer following `startxref` has trailing whitespace before the newline causing `Xref(Start)` errors. As far as I can tell, the pdf specification allows for one or more whitespace characters in many places so this seems like a bug to me.

title: Create rust.yml
body: Add github's standard Rust CI to prevent mistakes like mine in #101.

title: Fix compilation error&test error
body: Messed up in #101, also fix now non failing test.

title: Move bracket depth checking into parsers.

title: extend recursion limit to non-local references
body: Increase the scope of the recursion counter to the iterator instance to prevent more infinite recursion cases.

title: add indexing checks
body: Handle indexing errors a little friendlier than a panic.

title: Limit allowed bracket depth.
body: Handles stackoverflow.pdf in #82 more graciously.

title: keep looking for the last pattern
body:
`%%EOF` in the content overrides the proper eof

sample:
```pdf
4 0 obj
  << /Length 55 >>
stream
  BT
    /F1 18 Tf
    0 0 Td
(%%EOF startxref) Tj
  ET
endstream
endobj

xref
0 5
0000000000 65535 f 
0000000018 00000 n 
0000000077 00000 n 
0000000178 00000 n 
0000000457 00000 n 
trailer
  <<  /Root 1 0 R
      /Size 5
  >>
startxref
565
%%EOF

```

full pdf:
```pdf.base64
JVBERi0xLjEKJSUlJSUlJQoKMSAwIG9iagogIDw8IC9UeXBlIC9DYXRhbG9nCiAgICAgL1BhZ2Vz
IDIgMCBSCiAgPj4KZW5kb2JqCgoyIDAgb2JqCiAgPDwgL1R5cGUgL1BhZ2VzCiAgICAgL0tpZHMg

CjQgMCBvYmoKICA8PCAvTGVuZ3RoIDU1ID4+CnN0cmVhbQogIEJUCiAgICAvRjEgMTggVGYKICAg
IDAgMCBUZAooJSVFT0Ygc3RhcnR4cmVmKSBUagogIEVUCmVuZHN0cmVhbQplbmRvYmoKCnhyZWYK
```

title: check  that the buffer is big enough for startxref
body:
the pdf below triggers integer underflow

```pdf
%PDF-1.5
%%EOF
```

title: limit recursion to the number of objects
body:
a self referential pdf causes infinity loop.

```pdf
%PDF-1.5

1 0 obj
  << /Type /Catalog
     /Pages 2 0 R
  >>
endobj

2 0 obj
  << /Type /Pages
     /Kids [2 0 R]
  >>
endobj

xref
1 3
0000000000 65535 f 
0000000010 00000 n 
0000000069 00000 n 
trailer
  <<  /Root 1 0 R
      /Size 5
  >>
startxref
127
%%EOF


```

title: Update itoa and linked-hash-map
body: Those don't require any code changes.

title: More permissive datetime parsing
body:
When chrono_time is enabled, the datetime parser is now more
permissive and will also accept a datetime format where the seconds
are missing (like in the example from the PDF spec), and also just
a date without any time information. Defaults are used for the
missing fields, as required by the PDF spec.

This change solves most of the problems pointed out in #88. The parser will still choke on some datetime strings that the spec allows. You could for example just specify a year, or only the year and month. But I assume that's rather uncommon and as far as I am concerned the issue can be closed when this change is merged.

title: Fix datetime parser
body:
This fixes the timezone handling issue described in #88 

Note that the other issue (handling of incomplete date strings) is not addressed by this change. I would still suggest that this is merged. Addressing the other issue will most likely be a larger effort and it would be nice to get this fixed first.

title: Suggestion: don't rayon-parallelise when on wasm32
body:
For now, the story for spawning threads on wasm is not entirely settled (see the conversation in rayon-rs/rayon#636), meaning that using `par_iter()` and `par_chunks()` panics in the browser.

One solution is for lopdf consumers to follow the [parallel raytracing example](https://github.com/rustwasm/wasm-bindgen/tree/master/examples/raytrace-parallel) from wasm-bindgen, but [at the time of writing](https://github.com/rustwasm/wasm-bindgen/blob/025b1d8bca8f34b056672173077578b0d4d29551/examples/raytrace-parallel/build.sh) that makes building a binary pretty non-standard.

So this PR proposes to simply disable rayon parallelisation when building for wasm, until the story for wasm threads reaches a more stable state. Let me know what you think!

title: Validate objectid
body:
This fixes a stack overflow I hit.

I had a PDF file where the stream's length was considered at the same file offset as the stream. With this patch, when the object id is not the correct one, an error is signaled immediately.
